review.title: Multi-dimensional Parametric Mincuts for Constrained MAP Inference
review.abstract: In this paper, we propose novel algorithms for inferring the Maximum a Posteriori (MAP) solution of discrete pairwise random field models under multiple constraints. We show how this constrained discrete optimization problem can be formulated as a multi-dimensional parametric mincut problem via its Lagrangian dual, and prove that our algorithm isolates all constraint instances for which the problem can be solved exactly. These multiple solutions enable us to even deal with `soft constraints' (higher order penalty functions). Moreover, we propose two practical variants of our algorithm to solve problems with hard constraints. We also show how our method can be applied to solve various constrained discrete optimization problems such as submodular minimization and shortest path computation. Experimental evaluation using the foreground-background image segmentation problem with statistic constraints reveals that our method is faster and its results are closer to the ground truth labellings compared with the popular continuous relaxation based methods.

sections.heading: 1.1 Our contribution
sections.text: In this paper, we show how the problem of restricted discrete optimization associated with restricted MAP inference can be formulated as a multidimensional parametric thumbnail interface problem, and propose an algorithm that isolates all problems for which the problem can be accurately solved, resulting in many minimizers, each of which is optimal under certain conditions. These minimizers can be used to calculate good approximate solutions to problems with soft constraints (enforced with a higher term in energy). Our algorithm works by exploiting the minimization problem, and requires an oracle that efficiently calculates the values of the double-plane. A graph-intersection algorithm is a popular example of such an oracle.

sections.heading: 1.2 Related work
sections.text: A number of methods have been proposed to obtain better labeling solutions by deriving the MAP solution from a limited range of solutions that meet certain constraints, among which solutions to image caption problems that have a certain distribution of labels [36] or meet a topological property such as connectivity [32] have been extensively researched. Specifically, for the problem of foreground and background image segmentation, the most likely segmentations under the label number constraint have been found to be closer to the basic truth [14, 20]. Another example is the silhouette constraint used for the problem of 3D reconstruction [13, 29]. This constraint ensured that a beam emanating from each silhouette pixel must pass through at least one voxel belonging to the "object." Recently, a dual decomposition has been proposed to prevent such a MAP reference (7, 37).

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions
sections.text: Our AdaptSearch algorithm is capable of generating high-quality candidate solutions in a short space of time (see Figure 4) and can handle problems with very high job potential. We believe it would have a significant impact on solving many of the labeling problems that occur in computer vision and machine learning.
